page.title: 08LODSWORTH, SURREY TO SUSSEX
page.content: A Charter of Henry Ist dated 1119 mentions an exchange of land made by Richard de Balmas surnamed Rufus who later became{Bishop of London.}His successors{owned Lodsworth}until 1536 when Edward Bonner granted it to Henry VIII.Edward VI conveyed Lodsworth Manor to Anthony Browne of Cowdray.The inhabitants enjoyed the {LIBERTY OF {LODSWORTH,}subject to Church Law & not to Common Law.The village provided its own{Juries,}its own{Constables,}its own{Gallows}and its own{Prison}beneath the Manor House,where the Bishop's Steward lived ruling an estate and parish on the edge of the Weald Forest.(Up to 1900 the Church Vestry elected 6 constables annually.) County boundaries in the Forest were vague until 1100; the{1086 Domesday entries {for Lodsworth are listed under SURREY.
